Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Impact of Cardiovascular Drugs on Myocardial Injury After Noncardiac Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised controlled trial was conducted across multiple international centers

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants were adults undergoing noncardiac surgery, identified by elevated cTn levels within 30 days post-surgery

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either a regimen of cardiovascular drugs (aspirin, antihypertensives, statins) or standard care

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the efficacy of cardiovascular drugs in reducing mortality related to myocardial injury after noncardiac surgery (MINS)

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction in postoperative mortality within 30 days

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment achieved through sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group, recruited between January 2020 and June 2021

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, following an intention-to-treat approach

Result_Outcome.evidence: showing a significant effect size (hazard ratio = 0.75, 95% CI 0.60 to 0.90; p = 0.01)

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group experiencing mild gastrointestinal side-effects

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Institutes of Health
